results.title: Health
results.creator_credit: Robin James, Asian Studies Council, Griffith University and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Dragons tongue. - Series 2.”.
In this Chinese language program, Professor Colin Mackerras explores the many ways in which the Chinese people look after their health. Hospitals may be run by Government Departments for workers. Apart from conventional medicine, traditional therapies such as Acupuncture and Moxibustion are widely accepted. Herbal remedies are also important to Chinese medicine and many pharmacies carry both manufactured drugs and herbal treatments. This program also looks at the composition of a character when practising calligraphy.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robin James, Asian Studies Council, Griffith University and ABC-TV (Australia)

results.title: Families
results.creator_credit: Robin James, Asian Studies Council, Griffith University and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Dragons tongue. - Series 2.”.
In this Chinese language program, Professor Colin Mackerras looks at the importance of family in Chinese culture, especially since the law restricted family size to one child in order to contain the population. Chinese Law since the 1950’s forbade polygamy and arranged marriages, and now young people can choose their own partners. The status of women and girls is discussed and the problems encountered raising single children. The program also looks at oracle bones and how these lead to the creation of written language.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robin James, Asian Studies Council, Griffith University and ABC-TV (Australia)

results.title: Playing Fair
results.creator_credit: Wolf Koenig, Penny Ritco and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A series of four dramas for 7-12 year olds intended to promote discussion on the issues of racism, respect and equality for children. Each episode revolves around a conflict where a child is taunted and discriminated against because they are a member of a minority group. The situations are credible and expose the impact of such behaviour on children.

results.title: Walker
results.creator_credit: Alanis Obomsawin, Wolf Koenig, Penny Ritco and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Playing Fair”.
Walker is a young American Indian boy who has tragically lost his parents and is now fostered by another American Indian family. His only playmate and real companion is his dog. Jamie, a lonely young white boy has been made afraid, not only of dogs, but of people who are not white. Walker ignores the racist taunts and jeerings of the older boys who have influenced Jamie, and reaches out to him. Together they find friendship and understanding as Jamie learns to conquer his fears.

results.title: Hey, Kelly!
results.creator_credit: Sook-Yin Lee, Wolf Koenig, Penny Ritco and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Playing Fair”.
During a friendly game of tag, Robert calls Kelly a racist name and a fight ensues. Both Kelly and Robert are given detention, and the Principal gives them a task where they must co-operate in order to achieve the desired end. It is through this co-operation and working together, that Robert realises that he has a great deal in common with Kelly, and that her “difference” is only “skin-deep”.

results.title: Mela's lunch
results.creator_credit: Sugith Varughese, Wolf Koenig, Penny Ritco and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Playing Fair”.
Mela has just immigrated from India to Canada and is trying to settle into a new environment. Finding new friends and getting used to new surroundings becomes difficult because Peter and his classmates are determined to make her feel unwelcome and out of place. They jeer at her because her lunch is different and initially Allison goes along with the group, but realises this is unfair. Her decision to stick by Mela and to get to know her better demonstrate that differences in skin colour and country of origin should not be an obstacle to friendship and self-esteem.

results.title: Carol's mirror
results.creator_credit: Selwyn Jacob, Wolf Koenig, Penny Ritco and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Playing Fair”.
Nobody wants to play Snow White in this year’s drama production except for Carol. Previous years she had to be content to play lesser roles or the wicked witch. However, for some of her classmates this is a problem, because Carol is not white. After much lively debate and creative thinking, Carol and her classmates find a solution and show that the problem is not Carol’s colour, but that the material itself and people’s expectations about Snow White are the real obstacle.

results.title: The Western tradition
results.creator_credit: Metropolitan Museum of Art and WGBH Educational Foundation
results.brief_description: An absorbing survey of more than 2,000 years of Western civilisation giving students an educational foundation that will serve through college and beyond and providing adults with a chance to discover the history that has shaped our modern world. This encyclopaedic series is illustrated with over 2,700 paintings, sculptures and other records of the past compiled by the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Eloquent historian Eugen Weber guides the viewer through centuries of politics, literature, economics, industry, agriculture, art, philosophy and the daily lives of ordinary people.

group_works.title: The Renaissance and the world of discovery

results.title: The Renaissance & the new world
results.creator_credit: Metropolitan Museum of Art (New York, N.Y.) and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 26 of Series “The Western tradition”.
During the 15th and 16th Centuries, the Europeans were confronted by the discovery of new societies which challenged their understanding of the world and provoked a revolution in critical thinking. Prof. Eugen Weber asks,”What motivated the great explorers of the Renaissance, and how did their attitudes differ from a medieval mentality?” The New World was perceived as an earthly paradise and its people mythologised as “noble savages”. The importance of religion is explored, and how Christianity provided a rationale for slavery. Using Leonardo Da Vinci as a case study, Weber stresses the significance a new critical and comparative way of thinking, where knowledge was subject to revision on the basis of experience and observation.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Metropolitan Museum of Art (New York, N.Y.) and WGBH (Boston)

results.title: The American republic
results.creator_credit: Art Cohen, Metropolitan Museum of Art and WGBH Educational Foundation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Western tradition”.
This absorbing series is a survey of 2,000 years of Western civilisation illustrated by paintings, sculpture and other records from the past, compiled by the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Historian Eugen Weber analyses the American Republic which was comprised of radicals and conservatives and founded on the premises of “Universal Freedoms” for its inhabitants.
